title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.12 | 27-12-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiran Dasya Gyanan Janishalakaya

segments.key_quote: Now I shall begin the transcendental narration of the Lord Sri Krishna and topics of the birth activities and deliverance of King Parikshit, the sage amongst kings, as well as topics of the renunciation of the worldly order by the sons of Pandu.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam (1.7.12) that will be discussed, focusing on Suta Goswami's intention to narrate Krishna Katha through the stories of King Parikshit and the Pandavas.
segments.transcript: Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Janmadhyasya Yatonvaya Ditaratash Chartheshabhignya Svarat Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam Tatho Jaya Mudhirayet. In this session, we will be discussing from the twelfth verse of the seventh chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, Parikshito Atharajarsher Janma Karma Vilapanam Samsthamcha Panduputranam Vakshye Krishna Kathodayam. The meaning of this verse is, Suta Goswami addressed the rishis headed by Saunaka. What did Suta Goswami tell the sages? Now I shall begin the transcendental narration of the Lord Sri Krishna and topics of the birth activities and deliverance of King Parikshit, the sage amongst kings, as well as topics of the renunciation of the worldly order by the sons of Pandu.

segments.key_quote: What is the connection between Pandavas renouncing this world and Krishna Katha and again what is the connection between Pariksit's birth activities and deliverance with Krishna Katha
segments.summary: The speaker questions the connection between the stories of the Pandavas and Parikshit and Krishna Katha, setting the stage for Srila Prabhupada's explanation.
segments.transcript: See, Suta Goswami began telling the sage Sunaimishanya in the third chapter. After answering their initial six questions, Suta Goswami started telling them, "I see that you are very eager to hear about Krishna. So, best is that I narrate the Srimad Bhagavatam because Bhagavatam is Krishna Katha." Therefore, Suta Goswami said, here he is telling, "I shall begin transcendental narration of the Lord Shri Krishna," and how will he begin such a narration of Krishna Katha by narrating topics of the birth activities and deliverance of King Pariksit, the Raja Rishi, as well as topics of the renunciation of the worldly order by the sons of Pandu. By the Pandavas' renunciation, what is the connection between Pandavas renouncing this world and Krishna Katha? And again, what is the connection between Pariksit's birth activities and deliverance with Krishna Katha?

segments.key_quote: Any historical fact old or new which has a connection with the activities of the Supreme Lord Krishna is to be understood as a transcendental narration of the Lord Shri Krishna
segments.summary: The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's perspective that any historical fact connected to Krishna's activities is transcendental.
segments.transcript: So, Srila Prabhupada explains this very important point in the purport. Srila Prabhupada says, "Lord Krishna is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind to the forefathers of the world that he is so kind world transcendental appearance he also takes part with all kinds of living entities in daily activities which appear like ordinary activities but which are completely transcendental." So, Srila Prabhupada says, "Any historical fact, old or new, which has a connection with the activities of the Supreme Lord Krishna is to be understood as a transcendental narration of the Lord Shri Krishna." Narration about the activities of Krishna or any fact, historical fact, in connection with Krishna's activities is actually a transcendental narration of Krishna only.

segments.key_quote: Without Krishna all the supplementary literatures like the Puranas and Mahabharata are simply stories or historical facts but with Krishna in connection with Krishna they become transcendental
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the transcendental nature of Srimad Bhagavatam, emphasizing that it is centered around the activities of Lord Krishna, making it the 'spotless Purana'.
segments.transcript: Only without Krishna, all the supplementary literatures like the Puranas and Mahabharata are simply stories or historical facts, but with Krishna, in connection with Krishna, they become transcendental. The same historical narrations which are in relationship with Krishna become transcendental narrations, and without this Krishna, they are all material facts, material histories, that's all. When we hear the activities of the devotees of Krishna in relationship with Krishna, we at once become transcendental, related with Krishna, immediately the connection, spiritual connection, is established. So, Srimad Bhagavatam is also a Purana. Purana means that which contains a very ancient history. But the special significance of this Purana, Bhagavata Purana, is that the activities of the Lord are central and not just supplementary historical facts.

segments.key_quote: Everything is centered around the activities of Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates that the activities of Krishna are central to the Srimad Bhagavatam, making all narrations spiritual when connected to Him.
segments.transcript: The activities of Lord Krishna are central in this Purana, particularly. Srimad Bhagavatam is thus recommended by Lord Sri Krishna, sorry, Srimad Bhagavatam is thus recommended by Lord Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu as the spotless Purana. Chaitanya Mahaprabhu called this Amala Purana, spotless Purana. That means in this Purana, there is nothing material, no material subject matter. Birth, activities of Parikshit Maharaj, this is not material description because the central topic is the activities of Krishna. Everything is centered around the activities of Krishna. Every narration, you will find there is some relationship with activities of Krishna, connection with activities of Krishna. Without such connection with Krishna, none of these narrations are spiritual,

segments.key_quote: There is a class of less intelligent devotees of Bhagavata Purana who desire to relish at once the activities of the Lord narrated in the 10th canto without first understanding the primary cantos.
segments.summary: The speaker addresses the common misconception of skipping to the 10th canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, emphasizing the importance of understanding the preceding cantos as they are all spiritually significant and centered around Krishna.
segments.transcript: they are simply material. Now, here is an important point Prabhupada is stressing: "There is a class of less intelligent devotees of Bhagavata Purana who desire to relish at once the activities of the Lord narrated in the 10th canto without first understanding the primary cantos." See, Bhagavatam is presented by Vyasa Deva systematically in 12 cantos. 12 cantos, 1st canto, 2nd canto, 3rd canto. We are in the 1st canto now. Like this, there are 12 cantos. Each canto is very big. Each canto contains several chapters. Each chapter contains several verses. And each verses got so much of depth. We just went through the Atmarama verse. Chaitanya Mahaprabhu gave 61 meanings of the Atmarama verse. Of course, I didn't describe all the 61 meanings, but I described some of them. Like that Chaitanya Mahaprabhu points out there is so much depth in the Srimad Bhagavatam. This is the spotless Purana because it contains narrations of the activities of Krishna which are central to everything discussed in the Srimad Bhagavatam. So, it's not that the 10th canto which specifically describes Krishna's appearance and activities as the original personality of God alone is important. No. Every single canto of Bhagavatam, beginning from the 1st canto, is having spiritual description.

segments.key_quote: Beginning from the 1st canto is having spiritual description.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that Krishna appears in various forms and incarnations, and the activities of his pure devotees are also 100% spiritual.
segments.transcript: Descriptions of spiritual potency centered around the activities of the Supreme Personality of Godhead Krishna only. Krishna appears not only in his original form as Krishna. He also appears in his various forms. He also appears in his various forms. He also appears in his various forms. Transcendental forms of incarnation, Rama, Narasimha, Varaha, Matsya, Kurma, and so on. All those descriptions are there. And not only he himself, but his devotees, his pure devotees, the Pandavas, Parichit Maharaj, Shukadeva Goswami. Shukadev Goswami, all pure devotees' activities, their narrations, their histories, their descriptions, everything is 100% spiritual.

segments.key_quote: Devotees are never without Krishna. And Krishna is never without devotees.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that all cantos of the Srimad Bhagavatam are equally important and that devotees are always connected to Krishna.
segments.transcript: So, Srila Prabhupada clarifies, these people who jump to the 10th canto without reading or hearing or studying the first 9 cantos, they are under the false impression that the other cantos are not concerned with Krishna. That's what these foolish people think. And thus, more foolishly than intelligently, they take to the reading of the 10th canto. They directly jump to the 10th canto. They say, "We have nothing to do with Pandavas and Parikshit and Prithu Maharaj and Pracheya. All that we are not interested. We are only interested in Krishna, Krishna Leela." But actually, these readers are specifically told herein that the other cantos of the Bhagavatam are as important as the 10th canto. That's why, what does Suta Goswami tell the sages in this verse? Suta Goswami says, I am going to narrate the history of the birth, the activities, and deliverance of King Parikshit, as well as the topics of renunciation of the Pandavas. Now, what has that got to do with Krishna Katha? That is what exactly we have to do. We have to understand that devotees are never without Krishna, and Krishna is never without devotees. Neither does Krishna perform activities alone, nor do devotees perform any activity alone without Krishna. So, devotees are always situated in Krishna consciousness, and Krishna is always doing everything in relationship to Krishna. And Krishna is always involved in joint devotion to...

segments.key_quote: Talks about the devotees talks about krishna in relationship with the devotees or talks about the devotees in relationship with krishna everything is krishna katha
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating that any discussion about Krishna or his devotees is Krishna Katha, emphasizing their inseparable connection.
segments.transcript: Vyasa Deva, the author, is preparing the reader to better appreciate Krishna's transcendental activities in the tenth canto by describing the activities of Krishna's pure devotees and Krishna's incarnations in nine cantos, systematically develops the subject matter. So, Sridhar Prabhupada concludes by telling, Krishna and his pure devotees like the Pandavas are on the same plane, spiritual platform, pure devotional platform. Krishna is not without his devotees. Of all the rasas, Krishna is described as akhila rasamruta sindhu. He is full of varieties of rasas and his ocean of all rasas, and the pure devotees like Pandavas are not without Krishna. They are never without Krishna. So, the devotees and the Lord are interlinked, and they can never be separated, never. Therefore, talks about them all are Krishna Katha, talks about the devotees, talks about Krishna in relationship with the devotees, or talks about the devotees in relationship with Krishna, everything is Krishna Katha.
